A company is deploying User-ID in their network. The firewall team needs to have the ability to see and choose from a list of usernames and user groups directly inside the Panorama policies when creating new security rules.

An administrator is using Panorama and multiple Palo Alto Networks NGFWs. After upgrading all devices to the latest PAN-OSֲ® software, the administrator enables log forwarding from the firewalls to Panorama. Pre-existing logs from the firewalls are not appearing in Panorama.
Which action would enable the firewalls to send their pre-existing logs to Panorama?

choices.C: Use the ACC to consolidate pre-existing logs.
choices.D: The log database will need to exported form the firewalls and manually imported into Panorama.
choices.A: Use the import option to pull logs into Panorama.
choices.B: A CLI command will forward the pre-existing logs to Panorama.

discussion.content: correct

First, here is why it is NOT C: As others have pointed out, there is a link to a Palo Alto knowledge base describing the exact same behavior when enabling jumbo frames. There's one caveat, this issue is only seen in versions preceeding PAN-OS 9.0.10. "Resolution: Upgrade to PanOS version 9.0.10". Thus, this cannot be the a possible cuase in post PAN-OS 10.0.0. https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA14u000000HAZMCA4&lang=en_US%E2%80%A9

Argument for A: "Enable this option to forward segments and classify an application as unknown-tcp when the App-ID queue exceeds the 64-segment limit." Taken directly from https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-web-interface-help/device/device-setup-content-id

Selected Answer: C
So why can't it be C, everything seems to fit and I've seen it in live environment. 
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA14u000000HAZMCA4&lang=en_US%E2%80%A9

Here's why I think the answer is (A). The "enabling Forward segments that exceed the TCP App-ID inspection queue" is DISABELD by default, which means if you enable Jumbo frames on the firewall, and send large amount of traffic, the firewall should start dropping these packets with the default setting. I've seen the comments that there was a bug in previous PAN-OS versions where enabling Jumbo frames would display the same symptoms, but I don't think we can/should answer based on previous bugs, especially that the exam focuses on recent PAN-OS versions.

Selected Answer: A
I think A

Selected Answer: A
I would go with option A as C is only applicable to earlier OS versions. For people who are getting confused with question mentioning session discard, please read below.

If the session is in discard state, then the firewall discards the packet. The firewall can mark a session as being in the discard state due to a policy action change to deny (this could also occur if firewall has started to mark the app as unknown-tcp and there is no security policy to cater for unknown tcp traffic which means it will match the default interzone deny rule), or threat detection.

Selected Answer: C
it is answer C.
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA14u000000HAZMCA4&lang=en_US%E2%80%A9 this link is describing the exact same behavior when enabling jumbo frames
in this link https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-web-interface-help/device/device-setup-content-id here the PA wil still forward the traffic and the qeustion says "failing"

Selected Answer: A
Enable this option to forward segments and classify the application as unknown-tcp when the App-ID queue exceeds the 64-segment limit. Use the following global counter to view the number of segments in excess of this queue regardless of whether you enabled or disabled this option:
appid_exceed_queue_limit
Disable this option to prevent the firewall from forwarding TCP segments and skipping App-ID inspection when the App-ID inspection queue is full.

 
This option is disabled by default and you should leave it disabled for maximum security.
When you disable this option, you may notice increased latency on streams where more than 64 segments were queued awaiting App-ID processing.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
enabling Forward segments that exceed the TCP content inspection queue in Device > Setup > Content-ID > Content-ID Settings

choices.D: Jumbo frames were disabled on the firewall, which reduced the queue sizes dedicated for out-of-order and application identification.
choices.B: enabling Forward segments that exceed the TCP content inspection queue in Device > Setup > Content-ID > Content-ID Settings
choices.A: enabling Forward segments that exceed the TCP App-ID inspection queue in Device > Setup > Content-ID > Content-ID Settings
choices.C: Jumbo frames were enabled on the firewall, which reduced the App-ID queue size and the number of available packet buffers.

questions.question_text:
After some firewall configuration changes, an administrator discovers that application identification has started failing. The administrator investigates further and notices that a high number of sessions were going to a discard state with the application showing as unknown-tcp.
Which possible firewall change could have caused this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
In Panorama after you download the software you have the install button and then you are choosing devices. 
By default it is uploading and installing the software, but there is a check box if you want to upload the software only, and there is another check box if you want to reboot the device after installation.

comments.content: Also choosing three it makes sense to choose the three that state 'upload'

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
in the exam choose ACD
in my 11.1.3 PANO only "Reboot device after install" is available, which means you can't do an upload only on newer versions of the OS

Question is not very clear It says 
Which three actions can Panorama perform when deploying PAN-OS images to its managed devices?
Upload and install is default option 
Upload only is optional. You can tick that. 
Install and reboot is also an option available. 
Upload and Install (as one action ) and Reboot is also an option. 
All 4 can be done by Panorama 
Question can be interpreted in either way.

Selected Answer: ACD
On PCNSE exam, april 2024.

Selected Answer: ACD
On the "Deploy software" menu, there are 2 checkboxes
[ ] Upload only to device (do not install)
[  ] Reboot device after install

If you select none, it will upload and install. Answer is ACD

Selected Answer: ACD
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-web-interface-help/panorama-web-interface/panorama-device-deployment/manage-software-and-content-updates#id43219c23-b988-46d6-b5f0-d14df460b0f7

Selected Answer: ACD
ACD is correct. Once you download the relevant software in panorama, the default option is to upload and install the downloaded software (the firewall is needed to be rebooted manually in this case in order for the upgrade to complete). The other two options in the form of checkboxes at the bottom are: Upload Only to the device (do not install) & Reboot device after install (which works in conjunction with the default Upload and Install option i.e. upload+install+reboot).

Selected Answer: ACD
ACD
Upload only: 
Upload and install
Upload, install, and reboot

Selected Answer: ABD
cant install without reboot
ABD 

https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000Cm47CAC

Selected Answer: ACD
Please pay more attention to this question. There is a trap. The question asks " three actions can panorama perform" not "three options the user can select on Panorama". It means "Install and reboot" is totally false, because the panorama cannot install without uploading. The answer is ACD. 100% sure. 

See the video below if you cannot check it on panorama (12min02sec):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tOYXSLb8Uuk
ttps://www.kareemccie.com/2021/05/palo-alto-firewall-packet-flow.html

Selected Answer: ABD
A: valid option, upload-only. (Upload the image only and install and reboot at a later time)
B: valid option, once image has been uploaded (answer-A), a manual install and reboot can be done later
C: you cannot upload and install without reboot
D: upload and install and reboot. An upload and install is always followed by a reboot
E: not a valid option

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-web-interface-help/panorama-web-interface/panorama-device-deployment/manage-software-and-content-updates

comments.content: You absolutely can upload and install with out rebooting. The PANOS just wont be the new version until you reboot.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
ACD.
Upload only: This action uploads the PAN-OS image to the device but does not install it.

Upload and install: This action uploads the PAN-OS image to the device and installs it, but does not reboot the device.

Upload, install, and reboot: This action uploads the PAN-OS image to the device, installs it, and then reboots the device to complete the installation process.

Upload and install: This action uploads the PAN-OS image to the device and installs it, but does not reboot the device.

Upload, install, and reboot: This action uploads the PAN-OS image to the device, installs it, and then reboots the device to complete the installation process.

A. Upload only to device (software only)—Select to load the software without automatically installing it. 
B. Reboot device after install (software only)—Select to specify that the installation process automatically reboots the firewalls or Log Collectors.
D. Combination of A and B.
ABD Correct answer

questions.question_text: Which three actions can Panorama perform when deploying PAN-OS images to its managed devices? (Choose three.)

choices.C: Add the default Vulnerability Protection profile to all security rules that allow traffic from outside.
choices.D: Add a Zone Protection profile to the affected zones
choices.B: Enable packet buffer protection for the affected zones.
choices.A: Apply DOS profile to security rules allow traffic from outside.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
B Globally and then on the security zone

Selected Answer: B
Agree,B

Selected Answer: B
B
First globally then on the zone.

Selected Answer: B
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/zone-protection-and-dos-protection/zone-defense/packet-buffer-protection

B is correct; you must enable Packet Buffer Globally before you can enabled it per zone for a second level of protection

You Configure Packet Buffer Protection globally to protect the entire firewall and also enable Packet Buffer Protection on each zone to protect zones

Selected Answer: B
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/zone-protection-and-dos-protection/zone-defense/packet-buffer-protection

questions.question_text:
A firewall administrator is investigating high packet buffer utilization in the company firewall. After looking at the threat logs and seeing many flood attacks coming from a single source that are dropped by the firewall, the administrator decides to enable packet buffer protection to protect against similar attacks.
The administrator enables packet buffer protection globally in the firewall but still sees a high packet buffer utilization rate.
What else should the administrator do to stop packet buffers from being overflowed?
